# Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling Junyoung Chung       Caglar Gulcehre KyungHyun Cho Université de Montréal &Yoshua Bengio Université de Montréal CIFAR Senior Fellow ###### Abstract In this paper we compare different types of recurrent units in recurrent neural networks (RNNs). Especially, we focus on more sophisticated units that implement a gating mechanism, such as a long short-term memory (LSTM) unit and a recently proposed gated recurrent unit (GRU). We evaluate these recurrent units on the tasks of polyphonic music modeling and speech signal modeling. Our experiments revealed that these advanced recurrent units are indeed better than more traditional recurrent units such as tanh\\tanh units. Also, we found GRU to be comparable to LSTM. ## 1 Introduction Recurrent neural networks have recently shown promising results in many machine learning tasks, especially when input and/or output are of variable length (see, e.g., Graves, [2012](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib10 "")). More recently, Sutskever et al. ( [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib20 "")) and Bahdanau et al. ( [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib1 "")) reported that recurrent neural networks are able to perform as well as the existing, well-developed systems on a challenging task of machine translation. One interesting observation, we make from these recent successes is that almost none of these successes were achieved with a vanilla recurrent neural network. Rather, it was a recurrent neural network with sophisticated recurrent hidden units, such as long short-term memory units (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber, [1997](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib17 "")), that was used in those successful applications. Among those sophisticated recurrent units, in this paper, we are interested in evaluating two closely related variants. One is a long short-term memory (LSTM) unit, and the other is a gated recurrent unit (GRU) proposed more recently by Cho et al. ( [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib8 "")). It is well established in the field that the LSTM unit works well on sequence-based tasks with long-term dependencies, but the latter has only recently been introduced and used in the context of machine translation. In this paper, we evaluate these two units and a more traditional tanh\\tanh unit on the task of sequence modeling. We consider three polyphonic music datasets (see, e.g., Boulanger-Lewandowski et al., [2012](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib7 "")) as well as two internal datasets provided by Ubisoft in which each sample is a raw speech representation. Based on our experiments, we concluded that by using fixed number of parameters for all models on some datasets GRU, can outperform LSTM units both in terms of convergence in CPU time and in terms of parameter updates and generalization. ## 2 Background: Recurrent Neural Network A recurrent neural network (RNN) is an extension of a conventional feedforward neural network, which is able to handle a variable-length sequence input. The RNN handles the variable-length sequence by having a recurrent hidden state whose activation at each time is dependent on that of the previous time. More formally, given a sequence 𝐱=(𝐱1,𝐱2,⋯,𝐱T)𝐱subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2⋯subscript𝐱𝑇\\mathbf{x}=\\left(\\mathbf{x}\_{1},\\mathbf{x}\_{2},\\cdots,\\mathbf{x}\_{\\scriptscriptstyle{T}}\\right), the RNN updates its recurrent hidden state htsubscriptℎ𝑡h\_{t} by | | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | | 𝐡t=subscript𝐡𝑡absent\\displaystyle\\mathbf{h}\_{t}= | {0,t=0ϕ​(𝐡t−1,𝐱t),otherwisecases0𝑡0italic-ϕsubscript𝐡𝑡1subscript𝐱𝑡otherwise\\displaystyle\\begin{cases}0,&t=0\\\
\\phi\\left(\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1},\\mathbf{x}\_{t}\\right),&\\mbox{otherwise}\\end{cases} | | (1) | where ϕitalic-ϕ\\phi is a nonlinear function such as composition of a logistic sigmoid with an affine transformation. Optionally, the RNN may have an output 𝐲=(y1,y2,…,yT)𝐲subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2…subscript𝑦𝑇\\mathbf{y}=\\left(y\_{1},y\_{2},\\dots,y\_{\\scriptscriptstyle{T}}\\right) which may again be of variable length. Traditionally, the update of the recurrent hidden state in Eq. ( [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S2.E1 "In 2 Background: Recurrent Neural Network ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling")) is implemented as | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | | 𝐡t=g​(W​𝐱t+U​𝐡t−1),subscript𝐡𝑡𝑔𝑊subscript𝐱𝑡𝑈subscript𝐡𝑡1\\displaystyle\\mathbf{h}\_{t}=g\\left(W\\mathbf{x}\_{t}+U\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1}\\right), | | (2) | where g𝑔g is a smooth, bounded function such as a logistic sigmoid function or a hyperbolic tangent function. A generative RNN outputs a probability distribution over the next element of the sequence, given its current state 𝐡tsubscript𝐡𝑡\\mathbf{h}\_{t}, and this generative model can capture a distribution over sequences of variable length by using a special output symbol to represent the end of the sequence. The sequence probability can be decomposed into | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | | p​(x1,…,xT)=p​(x1)​p​(x2∣x1)​p​(x3∣x1,x2)​⋯​p​(xT∣x1,…,xT−1),𝑝subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑇𝑝subscript𝑥1𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥2subscript𝑥1𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥3subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2⋯𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑇subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑇1\\displaystyle p(x\_{1},\\dots,x\_{\\scriptscriptstyle{T}})=p(x\_{1})p(x\_{2}\\mid x\_{1})p(x\_{3}\\mid x\_{1},x\_{2})\\cdots p(x\_{\\scriptscriptstyle{T}}\\mid x\_{1},\\dots,x\_{\\scriptscriptstyle{T-1}}), | | (3) | where the last element is a special end-of-sequence value. We model each conditional probability distribution with | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | | p​(xt∣x1,…,xt−1)=𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑡1absent\\displaystyle p(x\_{t}\\mid x\_{1},\\dots,x\_{t-1})= | g​(ht),𝑔subscriptℎ𝑡\\displaystyle g(h\_{t}), | | where htsubscriptℎ𝑡h\_{t} is from Eq. ( [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S2.E1 "In 2 Background: Recurrent Neural Network ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling")). Such generative RNNs are the subject of this paper. Unfortunately, it has been observed by, e.g., Bengio et al. ( [1994](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib3 "")) that it is difficult to train RNNs to capture long-term dependencies because the gradients tend to either vanish (most of the time) or explode (rarely, but with severe effects). This makes gradient-based optimization method struggle, not just because of the variations in gradient magnitudes but because of the effect of long-term dependencies is hidden (being exponentially smaller with respect to sequence length) by the effect of short-term dependencies. There have been two dominant approaches by which many researchers have tried to reduce the negative impacts of this issue. One such approach is to devise a better learning algorithm than a simple stochastic gradient descent (see, e.g., Bengio et al., [2013](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib4 ""); Pascanu et al., [2013](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib19 ""); Martens and Sutskever, [2011](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib18 "")), for example using the very simple clipped gradient, by which the norm of the gradient vector is clipped, or using second-order methods which may be less sensitive to the issue if the second derivatives follow the same growth pattern as the first derivatives (which is not guaranteed to be the case). The other approach, in which we are more interested in this paper, is to design a more sophisticated activation function than a usual activation function, consisting of affine transformation followed by a simple element-wise nonlinearity by using gating units. The earliest attempt in this direction resulted in an activation function, or a recurrent unit, called a long short-term memory (LSTM) unit (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber, [1997](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib17 "")). More recently, another type of recurrent unit, to which we refer as a gated recurrent unit (GRU), was proposed by Cho et al. ( [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib8 "")). RNNs employing either of these recurrent units have been shown to perform well in tasks that require capturing long-term dependencies. Those tasks include, but are not limited to, speech recognition (see, e.g., Graves et al., [2013](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib13 "")) and machine translation (see, e.g., Sutskever et al., [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib20 ""); Bahdanau et al., [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib1 "")). ## 3 Gated Recurrent Neural Networks In this paper, we are interested in evaluating the performance of those recently proposed recurrent units (LSTM unit and GRU) on sequence modeling. Before the empirical evaluation, we first describe each of those recurrent units in this section. ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x1.png) ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x2.png) (a) Long Short-Term Memory (b) Gated Recurrent Unit Figure 1: Illustration of (a) LSTM and (b) gated recurrent units. (a) i𝑖i, f𝑓f and o𝑜o are the input, forget and output gates, respectively. c𝑐c and c~~𝑐\\tilde{c} denote the memory cell and the new memory cell content. (b) r𝑟r and z𝑧z are the reset and update gates, and hℎh and h~~ℎ\\tilde{h} are the activation and the candidate activation. ### 3.1 Long Short-Term Memory Unit The Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) unit was initially proposed by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber ( [1997](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib17 "")). Since then, a number of minor modifications to the original LSTM unit have been made. We follow the implementation of LSTM as used in Graves ( [2013](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib12 "")). Unlike to the recurrent unit which simply computes a weighted sum of the input signal and applies a nonlinear function, each j𝑗j-th LSTM unit maintains a memory ctjsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑗c\_{t}^{j} at time t𝑡t. The output htjsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑗h\_{t}^{j}, or the activation, of the LSTM unit is then | | | | | --- | --- | --- | | | htj=otj​tanh⁡(ctj),superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑜𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑗\\displaystyle h\_{t}^{j}=o\_{t}^{j}\\tanh\\left(c\_{t}^{j}\\right), | | where otjsuperscriptsubscript𝑜𝑡𝑗o\_{t}^{j} is an output gate that modulates the amount of memory content exposure. The output gate is computed by | | | | | --- | --- | --- | | | otj=σ​(Wo​𝐱t+Uo​𝐡t−1+Vo​𝐜t)j,superscriptsubscript𝑜𝑡𝑗𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑜subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑜subscript𝐡𝑡1subscript𝑉𝑜subscript𝐜𝑡𝑗\\displaystyle o\_{t}^{j}=\\sigma\\left(W\_{o}\\mathbf{x}\_{t}+U\_{o}\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1}+V\_{o}\\mathbf{c}\_{t}\\right)^{j}, | | where σ𝜎\\sigma is a logistic sigmoid function. Vosubscript𝑉𝑜V\_{o} is a diagonal matrix. The memory cell ctjsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑗c\_{t}^{j} is updated by partially forgetting the existing memory and adding a new memory content c~tjsuperscriptsubscript~𝑐𝑡𝑗\\tilde{c}\_{t}^{j} : | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | | ctj=ftj​ct−1j+itj​c~tj,superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡1𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript~𝑐𝑡𝑗\\displaystyle c\_{t}^{j}=f\_{t}^{j}c\_{t-1}^{j}+i\_{t}^{j}\\tilde{c}\_{t}^{j}, | | (4) | where the new memory content is | | | | | --- | --- | --- | | | c~tj=tanh(Wc𝐱t+Uc𝐡t−1)j.\\displaystyle\\tilde{c}\_{t}^{j}=\\tanh\\left(W\_{c}\\mathbf{x}\_{t}+U\_{c}\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1}\\right)^{j}. | | The extent to which the existing memory is forgotten is modulated by a forget gateftjsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑗f\_{t}^{j}, and the degree to which the new memory content is added to the memory cell is modulated by an input gateitjsuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑗i\_{t}^{j}. Gates are computed by | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | | ftj=superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑗absent\\displaystyle f\_{t}^{j}= | σ​(Wf​𝐱t+Uf​𝐡t−1+Vf​𝐜t−1)j,𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑓subscript𝐡𝑡1subscript𝑉𝑓subscript𝐜𝑡1𝑗\\displaystyle\\sigma\\left(W\_{f}\\mathbf{x}\_{t}+U\_{f}\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1}+V\_{f}\\mathbf{c}\_{t-1}\\right)^{j}, | | | | itj=superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑗absent\\displaystyle i\_{t}^{j}= | σ​(Wi​𝐱t+Ui​𝐡t−1+Vi​𝐜t−1)j.𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝐡𝑡1subscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝐜𝑡1𝑗\\displaystyle\\sigma\\left(W\_{i}\\mathbf{x}\_{t}+U\_{i}\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1}+V\_{i}\\mathbf{c}\_{t-1}\\right)^{j}. | | Note that Vfsubscript𝑉𝑓V\_{f} and Visubscript𝑉𝑖V\_{i} are diagonal matrices. Unlike to the traditional recurrent unit which overwrites its content at each time-step (see Eq. ( [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S2.E2 "In 2 Background: Recurrent Neural Network ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling"))), an LSTM unit is able to decide whether to keep the existing memory via the introduced gates. Intuitively, if the LSTM unit detects an important feature from an input sequence at early stage, it easily carries this information (the existence of the feature) over a long distance, hence, capturing potential long-distance dependencies. See Fig. [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S3.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ 3 Gated Recurrent Neural Networks ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling") (a) for the graphical illustration. ### 3.2 Gated Recurrent Unit A gated recurrent unit (GRU) was proposed by Cho et al. ( [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib8 "")) to make each recurrent unit to adaptively capture dependencies of different time scales. Similarly to the LSTM unit, the GRU has gating units that modulate the flow of information inside the unit, however, without having a separate memory cells. The activation htjsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑗h\_{t}^{j} of the GRU at time t𝑡t is a linear interpolation between the previous activation ht−1jsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡1𝑗h\_{t-1}^{j} and the candidate activation h~tjsuperscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑡𝑗\\tilde{h}\_{t}^{j}: | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | | htj=(1−ztj)​ht−1j+ztj​h~tj,superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡1𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑡𝑗\\displaystyle h\_{t}^{j}=(1-z\_{t}^{j})h\_{t-1}^{j}+z\_{t}^{j}\\tilde{h}\_{t}^{j}, | | (5) | where an update gateztjsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡𝑗z\_{t}^{j} decides how much the unit updates its activation, or content. The update gate is computed by | | | | | --- | --- | --- | | | ztj=σ​(Wz​𝐱t+Uz​𝐡t−1)j.superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡𝑗𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑧subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑧subscript𝐡𝑡1𝑗\\displaystyle z\_{t}^{j}=\\sigma\\left(W\_{z}\\mathbf{x}\_{t}+U\_{z}\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1}\\right)^{j}. | | This procedure of taking a linear sum between the existing state and the newly computed state is similar to the LSTM unit. The GRU, however, does not have any mechanism to control the degree to which its state is exposed, but exposes the whole state each time. The candidate activation h~tjsuperscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑡𝑗\\tilde{h}\_{t}^{j} is computed similarly to that of the traditional recurrent unit (see Eq. ( [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S2.E2 "In 2 Background: Recurrent Neural Network ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling"))) and as in (Bahdanau et al., [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib1 "")), | | | | | --- | --- | --- | | | h~tj=tanh(W𝐱t+U(𝐫t⊙𝐡t−1))j,\\displaystyle\\tilde{h}\_{t}^{j}=\\tanh\\left(W\\mathbf{x}\_{t}+U\\left(\\mathbf{r}\_{t}\\odot\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1}\\right)\\right)^{j}, | | where 𝐫tsubscript𝐫𝑡\\mathbf{r}\_{t} is a set of reset gates and ⊙direct-product\\odot is an element-wise multiplication. 111 Note that we use the reset gate in a slightly different way from the original GRU proposed in Cho et al. ( [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib8 "")). Originally, the candidate activation was computed by h~tj=tanh(W𝐱t+𝐫t⊙(U𝐡t−1))j,\\displaystyle\\tilde{h}\_{t}^{j}=\\tanh\\left(W\\mathbf{x}\_{t}+\\mathbf{r}\_{t}\\odot\\left(U\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1}\\right)\\right)^{j}, where rtjsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑗r\_{t}^{j} is a reset gate. We found in our preliminary experiments that both of these formulations performed as well as each other. When off (rtjsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑗r\_{t}^{j} close to 00), the reset gate effectively makes the unit act as if it is reading the first symbol of an input sequence, allowing it to forget the previously computed state. The reset gate rtjsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑗r\_{t}^{j} is computed similarly to the update gate: | | | | | --- | --- | --- | | | rtj=σ​(Wr​𝐱t+Ur​𝐡t−1)j.superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑗𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑟subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑟subscript𝐡𝑡1𝑗\\displaystyle r\_{t}^{j}=\\sigma\\left(W\_{r}\\mathbf{x}\_{t}+U\_{r}\\mathbf{h}\_{t-1}\\right)^{j}. | | See Fig. [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S3.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ 3 Gated Recurrent Neural Networks ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling") (b) for the graphical illustration of the GRU. ### 3.3 Discussion It is easy to notice similarities between the LSTM unit and the GRU from Fig. [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S3.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ 3 Gated Recurrent Neural Networks ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling"). The most prominent feature shared between these units is the additive component of their update from t𝑡t to t+1𝑡1t+1, which is lacking in the traditional recurrent unit. The traditional recurrent unit always replaces the activation, or the content of a unit with a new value computed from the current input and the previous hidden state. On the other hand, both LSTM unit and GRU keep the existing content and add the new content on top of it (see Eqs. ( [4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S3.E4 "In 3.1 Long Short-Term Memory Unit ‣ 3 Gated Recurrent Neural Networks ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling")) and ( [5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S3.E5 "In 3.2 Gated Recurrent Unit ‣ 3 Gated Recurrent Neural Networks ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling"))). This additive nature has two advantages. First, it is easy for each unit to remember the existence of a specific feature in the input stream for a long series of steps. Any important feature, decided by either the forget gate of the LSTM unit or the update gate of the GRU, will not be overwritten but be maintained as it is. Second, and perhaps more importantly, this addition effectively creates shortcut paths that bypass multiple temporal steps. These shortcuts allow the error to be back-propagated easily without too quickly vanishing (if the gating unit is nearly saturated at 111) as a result of passing through multiple, bounded nonlinearities, thus reducing the difficulty due to vanishing gradients (Hochreiter, [1991](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib16 ""); Bengio et al., [1994](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib3 "")). These two units however have a number of differences as well. One feature of the LSTM unit that is missing from the GRU is the controlled exposure of the memory content. In the LSTM unit, the amount of the memory content that is seen, or used by other units in the network is controlled by the output gate. On the other hand the GRU exposes its full content without any control. Another difference is in the location of the input gate, or the corresponding reset gate. The LSTM unit computes the new memory content without any separate control of the amount of information flowing from the previous time step. Rather, the LSTM unit controls the amount of the new memory content being added to the memory cell independently from the forget gate. On the other hand, the GRU controls the information flow from the previous activation when computing the new, candidate activation, but does not independently control the amount of the candidate activation being added (the control is tied via the update gate). From these similarities and differences alone, it is difficult to conclude which types of gating units would perform better in general. Although Bahdanau et al. ( [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib1 "")) reported that these two units performed comparably to each other according to their preliminary experiments on machine translation, it is unclear whether this applies as well to tasks other than machine translation. This motivates us to conduct more thorough empirical comparison between the LSTM unit and the GRU in this paper. ## 4 Experiments Setting ### 4.1 Tasks and Datasets We compare the LSTM unit, GRU and tanh\\tanh unit in the task of sequence modeling. Sequence modeling aims at learning a probability distribution over sequences, as in Eq. ( [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S2.E3 "In 2 Background: Recurrent Neural Network ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling")), by maximizing the log-likelihood of a model given a set of training sequences: | | | | | --- | --- | --- | | | max𝜽⁡1N​∑n=1N∑t=1Tnlog⁡p​(xtn∣x1n,…,xt−1n;𝜽),subscript𝜽1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑡1subscript𝑇𝑛𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑥1𝑛…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡1𝑛𝜽\\displaystyle\\max\_{\\boldsymbol{\\theta}}\\frac{1}{N}\\sum\_{n=1}^{N}\\sum\_{t=1}^{T\_{n}}\\log p\\left(x\_{t}^{n}\\mid x\_{1}^{n},\\dots,x\_{t-1}^{n};\\boldsymbol{\\theta}\\right), | | where 𝜽𝜽\\boldsymbol{\\theta} is a set of model parameters. More specifically, we evaluate these units in the tasks of polyphonic music modeling and speech signal modeling. For the polyphonic music modeling, we use three polyphonic music datasets from (Boulanger-Lewandowski et al., [2012](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib7 "")): Nottingham, JSB Chorales, MuseData and Piano-midi. These datasets contain sequences of which each symbol is respectively a 939393-, 969696-, 105105105-, and 108108108-dimensional binary vector. We use logistic sigmoid function as output units. We use two internal datasets provided by Ubisoft222 [http://www.ubi.com/](http://www.ubi.com/ "") for speech signal modeling. Each sequence is an one-dimensional raw audio signal, and at each time step, we design a recurrent neural network to look at 202020 consecutive samples to predict the following 101010 consecutive samples. We have used two different versions of the dataset: One with sequences of length 500500500 (Ubisoft A) and the other with sequences of length 8,00080008,000 (Ubisoft B). Ubisoft A and Ubisoft B have 7,23072307,230 and 800800800 sequences each. We use mixture of Gaussians with 20 components as output layer. 333Our implementation is available at [https://github.com/jych/librnn.git](https://github.com/jych/librnn.git "") ### 4.2 Models For each task, we train three different recurrent neural networks, each having either LSTM units (LSTM-RNN, see Sec. [3.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S3.SS1 "3.1 Long Short-Term Memory Unit ‣ 3 Gated Recurrent Neural Networks ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling")), GRUs (GRU-RNN, see Sec. [3.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S3.SS2 "3.2 Gated Recurrent Unit ‣ 3 Gated Recurrent Neural Networks ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling")) or tanh\\tanh units (tanh\\tanh-RNN, see Eq. ( [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S2.E2 "In 2 Background: Recurrent Neural Network ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling"))). As the primary objective of these experiments is to compare all three units fairly, we choose the size of each model so that each model has approximately the same number of parameters. We intentionally made the models to be small enough in order to avoid overfitting which can easily distract the comparison. This approach of comparing different types of hidden units in neural networks has been done before, for instance, by Gulcehre et al. ( [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib14 "")). See Table [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S4.T1 "Table 1 ‣ 4.2 Models ‣ 4 Experiments Setting ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling") for the details of the model sizes. | Unit | \# of Units | \# of Parameters | | Polyphonic music modeling | | LSTM | 36 | ≈19.8×103absent19.8superscript103\\approx 19.8\\times 10^{3} | | GRU | 46 | ≈20.2×103absent20.2superscript103\\approx 20.2\\times 10^{3} | | tanh\\tanh | 100 | ≈20.1×103absent20.1superscript103\\approx 20.1\\times 10^{3} | | Speech signal modeling | | LSTM | 195 | ≈169.1×103absent169.1superscript103\\approx 169.1\\times 10^{3} | | GRU | 227 | ≈168.9×103absent168.9superscript103\\approx 168.9\\times 10^{3} | | tanh\\tanh | 400 | ≈168.4×103absent168.4superscript103\\approx 168.4\\times 10^{3} | Table 1: The sizes of the models tested in the experiments. | | tanh\\tanh | GRU | LSTM | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Music Datasets | Nottingham | | | | --- | | train | | test | | | | | --- | | 3.22 | | 3.13 | | | | | --- | | 2.79 | | 3.23 | | | | | --- | | 3.08 | | 3.20 | | | JSB Chorales | | | | --- | | train | | test | | | | | --- | | 8.82 | | 9.10 | | | | | --- | | 6.94 | | 8.54 | | | | | --- | | 8.15 | | 8.67 | | | MuseData | | | | --- | | train | | test | | | | | --- | | 5.64 | | 6.23 | | | | | --- | | 5.06 | | 5.99 | | | | | --- | | 5.18 | | 6.23 | | | Piano-midi | | | | --- | | train | | test | | | | | --- | | 5.64 | | 9.03 | | | | | --- | | 4.93 | | 8.82 | | | | | --- | | 6.49 | | 9.03 | | | Ubisoft Datasets | Ubisoft dataset A | | | | --- | | train | | test | | | | | --- | | 6.29 | | 6.44 | | | | | --- | | 2.31 | | 3.59 | | | | | --- | | 1.44 | | 2.70 | | | Ubisoft dataset B | | | | --- | | train | | test | | | | | --- | | 7.61 | | 7.62 | | | | | --- | | 0.38 | | 0.88 | | | | | --- | | 0.80 | | 1.26 | | Table 2: The average negative log-probabilities of the training and test sets. We train each model with RMSProp (see, e.g., Hinton, [2012](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib15 "")) and use weight noise with standard deviation fixed to 0.0750.0750.075(Graves, [2011](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib11 "")). At every update, we rescale the norm of the gradient to 111, if it is larger than 111(Pascanu et al., [2013](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib19 "")) to prevent exploding gradients. We select a learning rate (scalar multiplier in RMSProp) to maximize the validation performance, out of 101010 randomly chosen log-uniform candidates sampled from 𝒰​(−12,−6)𝒰126\\mathcal{U}(-12,-6)~{}(Bergstra and Bengio, [2012](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib5 "")). The validation set is used for early-stop training as well. ## 5 Results and Analysis Table [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S4.T2 "Table 2 ‣ 4.2 Models ‣ 4 Experiments Setting ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling") lists all the results from our experiments. In the case of the polyphonic music datasets, the GRU-RNN outperformed all the others (LSTM-RNN and tanh\\tanh-RNN) on all the datasets except for the Nottingham. However, we can see that on these music datasets, all the three models performed closely to each other. On the other hand, the RNNs with the gating units (GRU-RNN and LSTM-RNN) clearly outperformed the more traditional tanh\\tanh-RNN on both of the Ubisoft datasets. The LSTM-RNN was best with the Ubisoft A, and with the Ubisoft B, the GRU-RNN performed best. In Figs. [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S5.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ 5 Results and Analysis ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling")– [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S5.F3 "Figure 3 ‣ 5 Results and Analysis ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling"), we show the learning curves of the best validation runs. In the case of the music datasets (Fig. [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S5.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ 5 Results and Analysis ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling")), we see that the GRU-RNN makes faster progress in terms of both the number of updates and actual CPU time. If we consider the Ubisoft datasets (Fig. [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#S5.F3 "Figure 3 ‣ 5 Results and Analysis ‣ Empirical Evaluation of Gated Recurrent Neural Networks on Sequence Modeling")), it is clear that although the computational requirement for each update in the tanh\\tanh-RNN is much smaller than the other models, it did not make much progress each update and eventually stopped making any progress at much worse level. These results clearly indicate the advantages of the gating units over the more traditional recurrent units. Convergence is often faster, and the final solutions tend to be better. However, our results are not conclusive in comparing the LSTM and the GRU, which suggests that the choice of the type of gated recurrent unit may depend heavily on the dataset and corresponding task. Per epoch ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x3.png) ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x4.png) Wall Clock Time (seconds) ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x5.png) ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x6.png) (a) Nottingham Dataset (b) MuseData Dataset Figure 2: Learning curves for training and validation sets of different types of units with respect to (top) the number of iterations and (bottom) the wall clock time. y-axis corresponds to the negative-log likelihood of the model shown in log-scale. Per epoch ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x7.png) ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x8.png) Wall Clock Time (seconds) ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x9.png) ![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555/assets/x10.png) (a) Ubisoft Dataset A (b) Ubisoft Dataset B Figure 3: Learning curves for training and validation sets of different types of units with respect to (top) the number of iterations and (bottom) the wall clock time. x-axis is the number of epochs and y-axis corresponds to the negative-log likelihood of the model shown in log-scale. ## 6 Conclusion In this paper we empirically evaluated recurrent neural networks (RNN) with three widely used recurrent units; (1) a traditional tanh\\tanh unit, (2) a long short-term memory (LSTM) unit and (3) a recently proposed gated recurrent unit (GRU). Our evaluation focused on the task of sequence modeling on a number of datasets including polyphonic music data and raw speech signal data. The evaluation clearly demonstrated the superiority of the gated units; both the LSTM unit and GRU, over the traditional tanh\\tanh unit. This was more evident with the more challenging task of raw speech signal modeling. However, we could not make concrete conclusion on which of the two gating units was better. We consider the experiments in this paper as preliminary. In order to understand better how a gated unit helps learning and to separate out the contribution of each component, for instance gating units in the LSTM unit or the GRU, of the gating units, more thorough experiments will be required in the future. ## Acknowledgments The authors would like to thank Ubisoft for providing the datasets and for the support. The authors would like to thank the developers of Theano (Bergstra et al., [2010](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib6 ""); Bastien et al., [2012](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib2 "")) and Pylearn2 (Goodfellow et al., [2013](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1412.3555#bib.bib9 "")). html:
Empirical Evaluation of
Gated Recurrent Neural Networks
on Sequence Modeling

Junyoung Chung       Caglar Gulcehre       KyungHyun Cho
Université de Montréal &Yoshua Bengio
Université de Montréal
CIFAR Senior Fellow
Abstract

In this paper we compare different types of recurrent units in recurrent neural networks (RNNs). Especially, we focus on more sophisticated units that implement a gating mechanism, such as a long short-term memory (LSTM) unit and a recently proposed gated recurrent unit (GRU). We evaluate these recurrent units on the tasks of polyphonic music modeling and speech signal modeling. Our experiments revealed that these advanced recurrent units are indeed better than more traditional recurrent units such as tanh\tanh units. Also, we found GRU to be comparable to LSTM.

1 Introduction

Recurrent neural networks have recently shown promising results in many machine learning tasks, especially when input and/or output are of variable length (see, e.g., Graves, 2012). More recently, Sutskever et al. (2014) and Bahdanau et al. (2014) reported that recurrent neural networks are able to perform as well as the existing, well-developed systems on a challenging task of machine translation.

One interesting observation, we make from these recent successes is that almost none of these successes were achieved with a vanilla recurrent neural network. Rather, it was a recurrent neural network with sophisticated recurrent hidden units, such as long short-term memory units (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber, 1997), that was used in those successful applications.

Among those sophisticated recurrent units, in this paper, we are interested in evaluating two closely related variants. One is a long short-term memory (LSTM) unit, and the other is a gated recurrent unit (GRU) proposed more recently by Cho et al. (2014). It is well established in the field that the LSTM unit works well on sequence-based tasks with long-term dependencies, but the latter has only recently been introduced and used in the context of machine translation.

In this paper, we evaluate these two units and a more traditional tanh\tanh unit on the task of sequence modeling. We consider three polyphonic music datasets (see, e.g., Boulanger-Lewandowski et al., 2012) as well as two internal datasets provided by Ubisoft in which each sample is a raw speech representation.

Based on our experiments, we concluded that by using fixed number of parameters for all models on some datasets GRU, can outperform LSTM units both in terms of convergence in CPU time and in terms of parameter updates and generalization.

2 Background: Recurrent Neural Network

A recurrent neural network (RNN) is an extension of a conventional feedforward neural network, which is able to handle a variable-length sequence input. The RNN handles the variable-length sequence by having a recurrent hidden state whose activation at each time is dependent on that of the previous time.

More formally, given a sequence 𝐱=(𝐱1,𝐱2,⋯,𝐱T)𝐱subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2⋯subscript𝐱𝑇\mathbf{x}=\left(\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{\scriptscriptstyle{T}}\right), the RNN updates its recurrent hidden state htsubscriptℎ𝑡h_{t} by

𝐡t=subscript𝐡𝑡absent\displaystyle\mathbf{h}_{t}= {0,t=0ϕ​(𝐡t−1,𝐱t),otherwisecases0𝑡0italic-ϕsubscript𝐡𝑡1subscript𝐱𝑡otherwise\displaystyle\begin{cases}0,&t=0\\ \phi\left(\mathbf{h}_{t-1},\mathbf{x}_{t}\right),&\mbox{otherwise}\end{cases} (1)

where ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is a nonlinear function such as composition of a logistic sigmoid with an affine transformation. Optionally, the RNN may have an output 𝐲=(y1,y2,…,yT)𝐲subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2…subscript𝑦𝑇\mathbf{y}=\left(y_{1},y_{2},\dots,y_{\scriptscriptstyle{T}}\right) which may again be of variable length.

Traditionally, the update of the recurrent hidden state in Eq. (1) is implemented as

𝐡t=g​(W​𝐱t+U​𝐡t−1),subscript𝐡𝑡𝑔𝑊subscript𝐱𝑡𝑈subscript𝐡𝑡1\displaystyle\mathbf{h}_{t}=g\left(W\mathbf{x}_{t}+U\mathbf{h}_{t-1}\right), (2)

where g𝑔g is a smooth, bounded function such as a logistic sigmoid function or a hyperbolic tangent function.

A generative RNN outputs a probability distribution over the next element of the sequence, given its current state 𝐡tsubscript𝐡𝑡\mathbf{h}_{t}, and this generative model can capture a distribution over sequences of variable length by using a special output symbol to represent the end of the sequence. The sequence probability can be decomposed into

p​(x1,…,xT)=p​(x1)​p​(x2∣x1)​p​(x3∣x1,x2)​⋯​p​(xT∣x1,…,xT−1),𝑝subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑇𝑝subscript𝑥1𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥2subscript𝑥1𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥3subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2⋯𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑇subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑇1\displaystyle p(x_{1},\dots,x_{\scriptscriptstyle{T}})=p(x_{1})p(x_{2}\mid x_{1})p(x_{3}\mid x_{1},x_{2})\cdots p(x_{\scriptscriptstyle{T}}\mid x_{1},\dots,x_{\scriptscriptstyle{T-1}}), (3)

where the last element is a special end-of-sequence value. We model each conditional probability distribution with

p​(xt∣x1,…,xt−1)=𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑡1absent\displaystyle p(x_{t}\mid x_{1},\dots,x_{t-1})= g​(ht),𝑔subscriptℎ𝑡\displaystyle g(h_{t}),

where htsubscriptℎ𝑡h_{t} is from Eq. (1). Such generative RNNs are the subject of this paper.

Unfortunately, it has been observed by, e.g., Bengio et al. (1994) that it is difficult to train RNNs to capture long-term dependencies because the gradients tend to either vanish (most of the time) or explode (rarely, but with severe effects). This makes gradient-based optimization method struggle, not just because of the variations in gradient magnitudes but because of the effect of long-term dependencies is hidden (being exponentially smaller with respect to sequence length) by the effect of short-term dependencies. There have been two dominant approaches by which many researchers have tried to reduce the negative impacts of this issue. One such approach is to devise a better learning algorithm than a simple stochastic gradient descent (see, e.g., Bengio et al., 2013; Pascanu et al., 2013; Martens and Sutskever, 2011), for example using the very simple clipped gradient, by which the norm of the gradient vector is clipped, or using second-order methods which may be less sensitive to the issue if the second derivatives follow the same growth pattern as the first derivatives (which is not guaranteed to be the case).

The other approach, in which we are more interested in this paper, is to design a more sophisticated activation function than a usual activation function, consisting of affine transformation followed by a simple element-wise nonlinearity by using gating units. The earliest attempt in this direction resulted in an activation function, or a recurrent unit, called a long short-term memory (LSTM) unit (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber, 1997). More recently, another type of recurrent unit, to which we refer as a gated recurrent unit (GRU), was proposed by Cho et al. (2014). RNNs employing either of these recurrent units have been shown to perform well in tasks that require capturing long-term dependencies. Those tasks include, but are not limited to, speech recognition (see, e.g., Graves et al., 2013) and machine translation (see, e.g., Sutskever et al., 2014; Bahdanau et al., 2014).

3 Gated Recurrent Neural Networks

In this paper, we are interested in evaluating the performance of those recently proposed recurrent units (LSTM unit and GRU) on sequence modeling. Before the empirical evaluation, we first describe each of those recurrent units in this section.

3.1 Long Short-Term Memory Unit

The Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) unit was initially proposed by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber (1997). Since then, a number of minor modifications to the original LSTM unit have been made. We follow the implementation of LSTM as used in Graves (2013).

Unlike to the recurrent unit which simply computes a weighted sum of the input signal and applies a nonlinear function, each j𝑗j-th LSTM unit maintains a memory ctjsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑗c_{t}^{j} at time t𝑡t. The output htjsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑗h_{t}^{j}, or the activation, of the LSTM unit is then

htj=otj​tanh⁡(ctj),superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑜𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑗\displaystyle h_{t}^{j}=o_{t}^{j}\tanh\left(c_{t}^{j}\right),

where otjsuperscriptsubscript𝑜𝑡𝑗o_{t}^{j} is an output gate that modulates the amount of memory content exposure. The output gate is computed by

otj=σ​(Wo​𝐱t+Uo​𝐡t−1+Vo​𝐜t)j,superscriptsubscript𝑜𝑡𝑗𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑜subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑜subscript𝐡𝑡1subscript𝑉𝑜subscript𝐜𝑡𝑗\displaystyle o_{t}^{j}=\sigma\left(W_{o}\mathbf{x}_{t}+U_{o}\mathbf{h}_{t-1}+V_{o}\mathbf{c}_{t}\right)^{j},

where σ𝜎\sigma is a logistic sigmoid function. Vosubscript𝑉𝑜V_{o} is a diagonal matrix.

The memory cell ctjsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑗c_{t}^{j} is updated by partially forgetting the existing memory and adding a new memory content c~tjsuperscriptsubscript~𝑐𝑡𝑗\tilde{c}_{t}^{j} :

ctj=ftj​ct−1j+itj​c~tj,superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡1𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript~𝑐𝑡𝑗\displaystyle c_{t}^{j}=f_{t}^{j}c_{t-1}^{j}+i_{t}^{j}\tilde{c}_{t}^{j}, (4)

where the new memory content is

c~tj=tanh(Wc𝐱t+Uc𝐡t−1)j.\displaystyle\tilde{c}_{t}^{j}=\tanh\left(W_{c}\mathbf{x}_{t}+U_{c}\mathbf{h}_{t-1}\right)^{j}.

The extent to which the existing memory is forgotten is modulated by a forget gate ftjsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑗f_{t}^{j}, and the degree to which the new memory content is added to the memory cell is modulated by an input gate itjsuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑗i_{t}^{j}. Gates are computed by

ftj=superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑗absent\displaystyle f_{t}^{j}= σ​(Wf​𝐱t+Uf​𝐡t−1+Vf​𝐜t−1)j,𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑓subscript𝐡𝑡1subscript𝑉𝑓subscript𝐜𝑡1𝑗\displaystyle\sigma\left(W_{f}\mathbf{x}_{t}+U_{f}\mathbf{h}_{t-1}+V_{f}\mathbf{c}_{t-1}\right)^{j},
itj=superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑗absent\displaystyle i_{t}^{j}= σ​(Wi​𝐱t+Ui​𝐡t−1+Vi​𝐜t−1)j.𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝐡𝑡1subscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝐜𝑡1𝑗\displaystyle\sigma\left(W_{i}\mathbf{x}_{t}+U_{i}\mathbf{h}_{t-1}+V_{i}\mathbf{c}_{t-1}\right)^{j}.

Note that Vfsubscript𝑉𝑓V_{f} and Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} are diagonal matrices.

Unlike to the traditional recurrent unit which overwrites its content at each time-step (see Eq. (2)), an LSTM unit is able to decide whether to keep the existing memory via the introduced gates. Intuitively, if the LSTM unit detects an important feature from an input sequence at early stage, it easily carries this information (the existence of the feature) over a long distance, hence, capturing potential long-distance dependencies.

See Fig. 1 (a) for the graphical illustration.

3.2 Gated Recurrent Unit

A gated recurrent unit (GRU) was proposed by Cho et al. (2014) to make each recurrent unit to adaptively capture dependencies of different time scales. Similarly to the LSTM unit, the GRU has gating units that modulate the flow of information inside the unit, however, without having a separate memory cells.

The activation htjsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑗h_{t}^{j} of the GRU at time t𝑡t is a linear interpolation between the previous activation ht−1jsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡1𝑗h_{t-1}^{j} and the candidate activation h~tjsuperscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑡𝑗\tilde{h}_{t}^{j}:

htj=(1−ztj)​ht−1j+ztj​h~tj,superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡1𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑡𝑗\displaystyle h_{t}^{j}=(1-z_{t}^{j})h_{t-1}^{j}+z_{t}^{j}\tilde{h}_{t}^{j}, (5)

where an update gate ztjsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡𝑗z_{t}^{j} decides how much the unit updates its activation, or content. The update gate is computed by

ztj=σ​(Wz​𝐱t+Uz​𝐡t−1)j.superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡𝑗𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑧subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑧subscript𝐡𝑡1𝑗\displaystyle z_{t}^{j}=\sigma\left(W_{z}\mathbf{x}_{t}+U_{z}\mathbf{h}_{t-1}\right)^{j}.

This procedure of taking a linear sum between the existing state and the newly computed state is similar to the LSTM unit. The GRU, however, does not have any mechanism to control the degree to which its state is exposed, but exposes the whole state each time.

The candidate activation h~tjsuperscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑡𝑗\tilde{h}_{t}^{j} is computed similarly to that of the traditional recurrent unit (see Eq. (2)) and as in (Bahdanau et al., 2014),

h~tj=tanh(W𝐱t+U(𝐫t⊙𝐡t−1))j,\displaystyle\tilde{h}_{t}^{j}=\tanh\left(W\mathbf{x}_{t}+U\left(\mathbf{r}_{t}\odot\mathbf{h}_{t-1}\right)\right)^{j},

where 𝐫tsubscript𝐫𝑡\mathbf{r}_{t} is a set of reset gates and ⊙direct-product\odot is an element-wise multiplication. 111 Note that we use the reset gate in a slightly different way from the original GRU proposed in Cho et al. (2014). Originally, the candidate activation was computed by h~tj=tanh(W𝐱t+𝐫t⊙(U𝐡t−1))j,\displaystyle\tilde{h}_{t}^{j}=\tanh\left(W\mathbf{x}_{t}+\mathbf{r}_{t}\odot\left(U\mathbf{h}_{t-1}\right)\right)^{j}, where rtjsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑗r_{t}^{j} is a reset gate. We found in our preliminary experiments that both of these formulations performed as well as each other. When off (rtjsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑗r_{t}^{j} close to 00), the reset gate effectively makes the unit act as if it is reading the first symbol of an input sequence, allowing it to forget the previously computed state.

The reset gate rtjsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑗r_{t}^{j} is computed similarly to the update gate:

rtj=σ​(Wr​𝐱t+Ur​𝐡t−1)j.superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑗𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑟subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑈𝑟subscript𝐡𝑡1𝑗\displaystyle r_{t}^{j}=\sigma\left(W_{r}\mathbf{x}_{t}+U_{r}\mathbf{h}_{t-1}\right)^{j}.

See Fig. 1 (b) for the graphical illustration of the GRU.

3.3 Discussion

It is easy to notice similarities between the LSTM unit and the GRU from Fig. 1.

The most prominent feature shared between these units is the additive component of their update from t𝑡t to t+1𝑡1t+1, which is lacking in the traditional recurrent unit. The traditional recurrent unit always replaces the activation, or the content of a unit with a new value computed from the current input and the previous hidden state. On the other hand, both LSTM unit and GRU keep the existing content and add the new content on top of it (see Eqs. (4) and (5)).

This additive nature has two advantages. First, it is easy for each unit to remember the existence of a specific feature in the input stream for a long series of steps. Any important feature, decided by either the forget gate of the LSTM unit or the update gate of the GRU, will not be overwritten but be maintained as it is.

Second, and perhaps more importantly, this addition effectively creates shortcut paths that bypass multiple temporal steps. These shortcuts allow the error to be back-propagated easily without too quickly vanishing (if the gating unit is nearly saturated at 111) as a result of passing through multiple, bounded nonlinearities, thus reducing the difficulty due to vanishing gradients (Hochreiter, 1991; Bengio et al., 1994).

These two units however have a number of differences as well. One feature of the LSTM unit that is missing from the GRU is the controlled exposure of the memory content. In the LSTM unit, the amount of the memory content that is seen, or used by other units in the network is controlled by the output gate. On the other hand the GRU exposes its full content without any control.

Another difference is in the location of the input gate, or the corresponding reset gate. The LSTM unit computes the new memory content without any separate control of the amount of information flowing from the previous time step. Rather, the LSTM unit controls the amount of the new memory content being added to the memory cell independently from the forget gate. On the other hand, the GRU controls the information flow from the previous activation when computing the new, candidate activation, but does not independently control the amount of the candidate activation being added (the control is tied via the update gate).

From these similarities and differences alone, it is difficult to conclude which types of gating units would perform better in general. Although Bahdanau et al. (2014) reported that these two units performed comparably to each other according to their preliminary experiments on machine translation, it is unclear whether this applies as well to tasks other than machine translation. This motivates us to conduct more thorough empirical comparison between the LSTM unit and the GRU in this paper.

4 Experiments Setting

4.1 Tasks and Datasets

We compare the LSTM unit, GRU and tanh\tanh unit in the task of sequence modeling. Sequence modeling aims at learning a probability distribution over sequences, as in Eq. (3), by maximizing the log-likelihood of a model given a set of training sequences:

max𝜽⁡1N​∑n=1N∑t=1Tnlog⁡p​(xtn∣x1n,…,xt−1n;𝜽),subscript𝜽1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑡1subscript𝑇𝑛𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑥1𝑛…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡1𝑛𝜽\displaystyle\max_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{t=1}^{T_{n}}\log p\left(x_{t}^{n}\mid x_{1}^{n},\dots,x_{t-1}^{n};\boldsymbol{\theta}\right),

where 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} is a set of model parameters. More specifically, we evaluate these units in the tasks of polyphonic music modeling and speech signal modeling.

For the polyphonic music modeling, we use three polyphonic music datasets from (Boulanger-Lewandowski et al., 2012): Nottingham, JSB Chorales, MuseData and Piano-midi. These datasets contain sequences of which each symbol is respectively a 939393-, 969696-, 105105105-, and 108108108-dimensional binary vector. We use logistic sigmoid function as output units.

We use two internal datasets provided by Ubisoft222 http://www.ubi.com/ for speech signal modeling. Each sequence is an one-dimensional raw audio signal, and at each time step, we design a recurrent neural network to look at 202020 consecutive samples to predict the following 101010 consecutive samples. We have used two different versions of the dataset: One with sequences of length 500500500 (Ubisoft A) and the other with sequences of length 8,00080008,000 (Ubisoft B). Ubisoft A and Ubisoft B have 7,23072307,230 and 800800800 sequences each. We use mixture of Gaussians with 20 components as output layer. 333Our implementation is available at https://github.com/jych/librnn.git

4.2 Models

For each task, we train three different recurrent neural networks, each having either LSTM units (LSTM-RNN, see Sec. 3.1), GRUs (GRU-RNN, see Sec. 3.2) or tanh\tanh units (tanh\tanh-RNN, see Eq. (2)). As the primary objective of these experiments is to compare all three units fairly, we choose the size of each model so that each model has approximately the same number of parameters. We intentionally made the models to be small enough in order to avoid overfitting which can easily distract the comparison. This approach of comparing different types of hidden units in neural networks has been done before, for instance, by Gulcehre et al. (2014). See Table 1 for the details of the model sizes.

We train each model with RMSProp (see, e.g., Hinton, 2012) and use weight noise with standard deviation fixed to 0.0750.0750.075 (Graves, 2011). At every update, we rescale the norm of the gradient to 111, if it is larger than 111 (Pascanu et al., 2013) to prevent exploding gradients. We select a learning rate (scalar multiplier in RMSProp) to maximize the validation performance, out of 101010 randomly chosen log-uniform candidates sampled from 𝒰​(−12,−6)𝒰126\mathcal{U}(-12,-6)~{}(Bergstra and Bengio, 2012). The validation set is used for early-stop training as well.

5 Results and Analysis

Table 2 lists all the results from our experiments. In the case of the polyphonic music datasets, the GRU-RNN outperformed all the others (LSTM-RNN and tanh\tanh-RNN) on all the datasets except for the Nottingham. However, we can see that on these music datasets, all the three models performed closely to each other.

On the other hand, the RNNs with the gating units (GRU-RNN and LSTM-RNN) clearly outperformed the more traditional tanh\tanh-RNN on both of the Ubisoft datasets. The LSTM-RNN was best with the Ubisoft A, and with the Ubisoft B, the GRU-RNN performed best.

In Figs. 2–3, we show the learning curves of the best validation runs. In the case of the music datasets (Fig. 2), we see that the GRU-RNN makes faster progress in terms of both the number of updates and actual CPU time. If we consider the Ubisoft datasets (Fig. 3), it is clear that although the computational requirement for each update in the tanh\tanh-RNN is much smaller than the other models, it did not make much progress each update and eventually stopped making any progress at much worse level.

These results clearly indicate the advantages of the gating units over the more traditional recurrent units. Convergence is often faster, and the final solutions tend to be better. However, our results are not conclusive in comparing the LSTM and the GRU, which suggests that the choice of the type of gated recurrent unit may depend heavily on the dataset and corresponding task.

6 Conclusion

In this paper we empirically evaluated recurrent neural networks (RNN) with three widely used recurrent units; (1) a traditional tanh\tanh unit, (2) a long short-term memory (LSTM) unit and (3) a recently proposed gated recurrent unit (GRU). Our evaluation focused on the task of sequence modeling on a number of datasets including polyphonic music data and raw speech signal data.

The evaluation clearly demonstrated the superiority of the gated units; both the LSTM unit and GRU, over the traditional tanh\tanh unit. This was more evident with the more challenging task of raw speech signal modeling. However, we could not make concrete conclusion on which of the two gating units was better.

We consider the experiments in this paper as preliminary. In order to understand better how a gated unit helps learning and to separate out the contribution of each component, for instance gating units in the LSTM unit or the GRU, of the gating units, more thorough experiments will be required in the future.
